data.title: Planned St. Paul Lafayette Bridge ramps: still convoluted
data.meta_description: The new Lafayette Bridge in St. Paul will arc gently and simply over the Mississippi River, but it will finish with a flourish of underpasses and looping turns that some St. Paul leaders worry will confound drivers. “You’re going under three bridges and over the woods and through the valley before you get to Seventh […]
data.text:
To place an obituary, please include the information from the obituary checklist below in an email to obits@pioneerpress.com. There is no option to place them through our website. Feel free to contact our obituary desk at 651-228-5263 with any questions.

General Information:

Your full name,

Address (City, State, Zip Code),

Phone number,

And an alternate phone number (if any)

Obituary Specification:

Name of Deceased,

Obituary Text,

A photo in a JPEG or PDF file is preferable, TIF and other files are accepted, we will contact you if there are any issues with the photo.

Ad Run dates

There is a discount for running more than one day, but this must be scheduled on the first run date to apply.

If a photo is used, it must be used for both days for the discount to apply, contact us for more information.

Policies:

Verification of Death:

In order to publish obituaries a name and phone number of funeral home/cremation society is required. We must contact the funeral home/cremation society handling the arrangements during their business hours to verify the death. If the body of the deceased has been donated to the University of Minnesota Anatomy Bequest Program, or a similar program, their phone number is required for verification.

Please allow enough time to contact them especially during their limited weekend hours.

A death certificate is also acceptable for this purpose but only one of these two options are necessary.

Guestbook and Outside Websites:

We are not allowed to reference other media sources with a guestbook or an obituary placed elsewhere when placing an obituary in print and online. We may place a website for a funeral home or a family email for contact instead; contact us with any questions regarding this matter.

Obituary Process:

Once your submission is completed, we will fax or email a proof for review prior to publication in the newspaper. This proof includes price and days the notice is scheduled to appear.

Please review the proof carefully. We must be notified of errors or changes before the notice appears in the Pioneer Press based on each day’s deadlines.

After publication, we will not be responsible for errors that may occur after final proofing.

Online:

All obituaries appear on TwinCities.com with a permanent online guestbook presence. If you wish to have the online presence removed, you can contact us to remove the guestbook online. Changes to an online obituary can be handled through the obituary desk. Call us with further questions.

Payment Procedure:

Pre-payment is required for all obituary notices prior to publication by the deadline specified below in our deadline schedule. Please call 651-228-5263 with your payment information after you have received the proof and approved its contents.

Credit Card: Payment accepted by phone only due to PCI (Payment Card Industry) regulations

EFT: Check by phone. Please provide your routing number and account number.

Cash: Accepted at our FRONT COUNTER Monday – Friday from 8:00AM – 3:30PM

Rates:

The minimum charge is $162 for the first 10 lines.

Every line after the first 10 is $12.20.

If the ad is under 10 lines it will be charged the minimum rate of $162.

On a second run date, the lines are $8.20 per line, starting w/ the first line.

For example: if first run date was 20 lines the cost would be $164.

Each photo published is $125 per day.

For example: 2 photos in the paper on 2 days would be 4 photo charges at $500.

Deadlines:

Please follow deadline times to ensure your obituary is published on the day requested.

Hours

Deadline (no exceptions)

Ad

Photos

MEMORIAM (NON-OBITUARY) REQUEST

Unlike an obituary, Memoriam submissions are remembrances of a loved one who has passed. The rates for a memoriam differ from obituaries.

Please call or email us for more memoriam information

Please call 651-228-5280 for more information.

HOURS: Monday – Friday 8:00AM – 5:00PM (CLOSED WEEKENDS and HOLIDAYS)

Please submit your memoriam ad to memoriams@pioneerpress.com or call 651-228-5280.

The new Lafayette Bridge in St. Paul will arc gently and simply over the Mississippi River, but it will finish with a flourish of underpasses and looping turns that some St. Paul leaders worry will confound drivers.

“You’re going under three bridges and over the woods and through the valley before you get to Seventh Street,” St. Paul City Council President Kathy Lantry said. “Both council member (Dave) Thune and I are displeased. (But) as far as I can tell, I don’t know there’s a darned thing we can do about it.”

Engineers faced such challenges in designing the $190 million project to replace the aging U.S. 52 bridge that there might not be any other way, Lantry conceded.

Last week, the city council signed off on the Minnesota Department of Transportation’s near-final designs. Rough construction schedules call for much of the work to take place between next year and 2014. Traffic always will be able to cross the river, either on existing spans or new ones.

With aircraft height restrictions overhead, watercraft clearances below and little real estate to work with as U.S. 52 approaches Interstate 94 and East Seventh Street east of downtown, engineers and architects had only 13 feet of vertical distance to construct the bridge.

The result is an utterly utilitarian design, with no sweeping arches or soaring spires. The only question remaining is whether it will be concrete or steel.

When it came to figuring out how to connect the bridge with streets and highways north of the river, however, engineers drew up 22 variations, some stretching as far north as East Eighth Street.

In a traffic engineer’s perfect world, the project would have examined completely rebuilding the interchanges between not just U.S. 52 and I-94, but also feeder ramps to I-35E and exits to downtown.

“To really improve the north end of the Lafayette Bridge, you would have to alter 94 and 35E, and where do you stop?” said Wayne Norris, MnDOT’s north area manager. “This is a bridge replacement.”

Structurally speaking, the 42-year-old Lafayette Bridge is in worse shape than the Minneapolis I-35W bridge was before it collapsed in 2007. Like that bridge, the Lafayette is classified as “fracture-critical,” meaning if certain key parts of the bridge fail, the entire thing could collapse. Today’s bridges are designed with a level of redundancy so that can’t happen.

Officials said the Lafayette is in no danger of immediate collapse, but replacing it is a top MnDOT priority — and addressing the larger traffic picture of I-94 and I-35E isn’t part of that plan. Nonetheless, engineers did put a priority on addressing a few current safety issues.

Today, the bridge empties straight into Seventh Street at a four-way intersection. In addition to creating large backups in rush hour, the layout has led to a notorious pattern of crashes into Red’s Savoy Pizza restaurant, which faces the intersection.

And traffic from U.S. 52 to westbound I-94 is forced to make an unusually tight curl between Seventh and the interstate.

Financially and politically wary of condemning much land to address these problems, engineers, following a community feedback process, selected a final design with wider loops that go beneath roads rather than between them.

While traffic will get on 52 from Seventh at the same spot it does today, traffic getting off 52 onto East Seventh will actually end up east of Red’s Savoy — facing south.

“Where there is one really busy intersection today, we’ve split that intersection up into two intersections,” Norris said. Engineers maintain their final selection is safer and smoother for traffic than today’s cramped layout. But Lantry said the changes are so dramatic and different from what generations of drivers are accustomed to that it could spell trouble.

“People are going to be so turned around,” she said at last week’s council meeting. “They’re going to be going north to go south and west to go east and they’re going to come out at the corner of Kittson and Seventh Street, where they never thought they would be.”

Carol Carey, who chairs the lower Phalen Creek Project, said a straight connection to Seventh would cost less and be less confusing. It would also be less ugly, she said.

“After leaving the bridge, users will travel past a salt shed, under three bridges, along a set of railroad tracks — and as they wind up on Seventh Street, they will have a 360-degree view of a pawnshop,” she wrote in a letter to the city. “This is the ‘gateway’ to our communities created by the alignment.”

St. Paul City Engineer John Maczko assured the city council that the new interchange would be clearly marked — and well-landscaped. “I think people will be pleasantly surprised,” he said. “And I think it’ll be pretty obvious where to go.”

Take A Test Drive

Follow MnDOT’s 3D drive-through simulation of the U.S. 52-Interstate-94-East Seventh Street interchange at TwinCities.com.

Originally Published: June 19, 2010 at 11:01 p.m.
